awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  A New Class of High-Conductivity Solid-state Composite Electrolytes for Next-Generation Lithium Batteries
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovative Research (SBIR) Phase II project is the introduction of non-flammable, easy-to-manufacture solid battery electrolytes that are also compatible with lithium metal. The cell architecture seeks to ensure safety while enabling a significant improvement in the energy density.  The teams also seeks to lower the costs of the lithium-ion batteries by eliminating extrinsic costs associated with thermal management and explosion containment.  Safe, easy-to-manufacture electrolytes may alter the rate of electrification of the global economy. The next generation of battery powered medical devices, a large proportion of which are manufactured in the United States, may also benefit from the adoption of the new solid electrolyte. In addition, the proposed composite solid electrolyte aims to enable new cell architectures with significantly higher energy densities than what has been possible in liquid electrolyte systems to date.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project will develop a non-flammable, high-conductivity composite, solid-state battery electrolytes that are compatible with mixed metal oxide cathode chemistries and cell manufacturing processes. The morphology of the composite electrolyte is such that it offsets disadvantages present in polymer electrolytes, as well as inorganic sulfide and oxide solid electrolytes, when they are used as monolithic materials. The unique heterostructures of the proposed solid electrolytes advance the current state-of-the-art by enabling faster diffusion of lithium ions through multiple pathways, while mitigating the growth of lithium dendrites. The electrolyte's nonflammable nature makes it a potential replacement for conventional liquid electrolytes in reducing fire hazards and reducing the costs of reqired thermal protection systems in lithium-ion batteries. The compatibility with lithium metal presents a unique opportunity for improvement in the energy density over currently used silicon-graphite anodes, that translates to a lower cost per unit of stored energy ($/kWh). An additional advantage is that these batteries do not require special handling and they are compatible with both spiral wound and planar battery form factors.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Li-CFx Primary Battery and LFP Secondary Battery with All-Solid-State Construction

 NextGen Battery Technologies

Background

All-solid-state batteries (ASSBs) promise improved safety and energy density while enabling simpler manufacturing processes and reduced system costs.  ASSBs reduce the risk of thermal runaway, flame propagation, and dendrite formation, making them ideal for batteries with lithium metal anodes.

Adoption of ASSBs has faced challenges, including low ionic conductivity, reduced low-temperature performance, high electrolyte-electrode interfacial resistance, and differing functional requirements for the solid electrolyte/separator component versus the electrolyte within the cathode.

NextGen has advanced the state of ASSBs by recognizing the need for a dual-duty electrolyte solution. This transformative approach has resulted in a solid electrolyte system that addresses both functional requirements and can be tailored for diverse applications.  NextGen’s ASSB solution, therefore, will have broad impact across the spectrum of ASSBs, including both primary and rechargeable chemistries, in an unlimited range of defense, medical, industrial, and consumer products.

 

Development

NextGen optimized a non-flammable solid-polymer electrolyte (SPE) for both primary lithium-carbon-monofluoride (Li-CFx) and rechargeable lithium-iron-phosphate (LFP) batteries. Testing, guided by Industrial Partners, confirmed successful performance.

Six images are attached and referenced in the following discussion.

 

Flammability and Electrochemical Stability

Figure 1a shows that NextGen’s freestanding (SPE) film discolors but remains intact and exhibits no flame propagation when exposed to propane flame.

Linear sweep voltammetry In Figure 1b confirms superior high-voltage stability of the SPE at ~4.5V versus liquid electrolyte at ~3.5V.  

 

  1. 1.     Li-CFx Primary Battery

Known for exceptional energy density, up to 2180 Wh/kg, Li-CFx batteries are crucial for medical devices and defense applications. However, higher internal resistance impacts discharge voltage and rate capability. NextGen’s SPE enhances stability, mechanical resilience, and safety, while the fluorine diffusion rate of CFx chemistry itself limits discharge rates.

Figure 2 shows NextGen’s cell architecture used to evaluate the dual-electrolyte approach. SPE dispersed within the cathode is depicted as Polymer 1 (P1) while the free-standing separator/SPE is designated Polymer 2 (P2). Tuning P1 and P2 independently to balance between ionic conductivity and mechanical properties yields optimal cell performance and manufacturability.

 

Figure 3 shows NextGen Li-CFx ASSB cells performing consistently across temperatures (25℃ to 60℃) with performance comparable to commercial Li-CFx cells with flammable liquid electrolytes. Voltages are comparable to commercially available high-performance Li-CFx batteries while the lower voltage (1.8 V) plateau provides early indication for battery replacement as well as delivering additional capacity for products capable of operating at this voltage level. Meaningful capacity and voltage was also demonstrated at 0℃ and stable performance well above 60℃ is predicted.

Figure 4 demonstrates ability of NextGen’s Li-CFx ASSB to support pulse currents, such as for telemetry communications, and to recover quickly from those pulses, throughout the life of the battery. Pulses of C/200, C/100, and C/75 were applied every 24 hours, with a background discharge of C/1000. Voltage drop at the highest pulse rate is relatively low at ~0.05V and continues throughout the discharge.

 

Mitigation of Li-CFx Swelling

Conventional CFx electrodes expand up to 100% during discharge. Manufacturers compensate by varying the cathode composition, adjusting cell design, or underfilling the cell. SEM images in Figure 5 show that NextGen’s SPE reduces expansion to as little as 38%. Two cell configurations were analyzed, one with solid electrolyte in the cathode plus conventional liquid electrolyte, and a second with solid electrolyte both in the cathode and as separator, i.e., ASSB, with cathode thicknesses measured before and after full discharge.

The post-discharge expansion percentages in the table below compare (1) literature data for conventional liquid electrolyte, (2) cell with NextGen’s SPE P1 in the cathode and liquid electrolyte in the separator, (3) cell with NextGen’s SPE P1 in the cathode and SPE P2 as the separator.

Source of Data

Electrolyte Placement

Volume Change

1 – Literature, above

Total Liquid Electrolyte

~100 %

2 – NextGen SEM

SPE in Cathode, LE in separator

53%

3 – NextGen SEM

SPE throughout, i.e., ASSB

38%

 

  1. 2.     LiFePO4 Rechargeable Battery:

Figure 6 shows rate performance and cycling capacity retention for ASSB cells using LiFePO4 (LFP). Initial capacity at C/20 reached 170 mAh/g, with sustained capacity at rates as high as 1C charge/discharge. This indicates excellent rate performance for NextGen’s SPE in an LFP-based battery as it is challenging to achieve good rate performance with LFP, even in a liquid electrolyte system. Following the high-rate testing, cycle life testing showed excellent capacity retention with ~98% capacity projected after 500 cycles and ~96% after 1000 cycles.

  1. 3.     Conclusion

NextGen optimized Li-CFx and Li-LFP all-solid-state battery (ASSB) performance with a dual-duty solid electrolyte. ASSB Li-CFx and Li-LFP cell performance is approaching that of conventional liquid-electrolyte batteries while delivering critical safety and performance advantages. These innovations position NextGen as a leader in ASSB technology with beneficial implications for a broad range of industries and for society.

 


Last Modified: 04/10/2025
Modified by: Grant Farrell

Li-CFx Primary Battery and LFP Secondary Battery with All-Solid-State Construction


NextGen Battery Technologies


Background


All-solid-state batteries (ASSBs) promise improved safety and energy density while enabling simpler manufacturing processes and reduced system costs. ASSBs reduce the risk of thermal runaway, flame propagation, and dendrite formation, making them ideal for batteries with lithium metal anodes.


Adoption of ASSBs has faced challenges, including low ionic conductivity, reduced low-temperature performance, high electrolyte-electrode interfacial resistance, and differing functional requirements for the solid electrolyte/separator component versus the electrolyte within the cathode.


NextGen has advanced the state of ASSBs by recognizing the need for a dual-duty electrolyte solution. This transformative approach has resulted in a solid electrolyte system that addresses both functional requirements and can be tailored for diverse applications. NextGens ASSB solution, therefore, will have broad impact across the spectrum of ASSBs, including both primary and rechargeable chemistries, in an unlimited range of defense, medical, industrial, and consumer products.





Development


NextGen optimized a non-flammable solid-polymer electrolyte (SPE) for both primary lithium-carbon-monofluoride (Li-CFx) and rechargeable lithium-iron-phosphate (LFP) batteries. Testing, guided by Industrial Partners, confirmed successful performance.


Six images are attached and referenced in the following discussion.





Flammability and Electrochemical Stability


Figure 1a shows that NextGens freestanding (SPE) film discolors but remains intact and exhibits no flame propagation when exposed to propane flame.


Linear sweep voltammetry In Figure 1b confirms superior high-voltage stability of the SPE at ~4.5V versus liquid electrolyte at ~3.5V. 




1. Li-CFx Primary Battery



Known for exceptional energy density, up to 2180 Wh/kg, Li-CFx batteries are crucial for medical devices and defense applications. However, higher internal resistance impacts discharge voltage and rate capability. NextGens SPE enhances stability, mechanical resilience, and safety, while the fluorine diffusion rate of CFx chemistry itself limits discharge rates.


Figure 2 shows NextGens cell architecture used to evaluate the dual-electrolyte approach. SPE dispersed within the cathode is depicted as Polymer 1 (P1) while the free-standing separator/SPE is designated Polymer 2 (P2). Tuning P1 and P2 independently to balance between ionic conductivity and mechanical properties yields optimal cell performance and manufacturability.





Figure 3 shows NextGen Li-CFx ASSB cells performing consistently across temperatures (25℃ to 60℃) with performance comparable to commercial Li-CFx cells with flammable liquid electrolytes. Voltages are comparable to commercially available high-performance Li-CFx batteries while the lower voltage (1.8 V) plateau provides early indication for battery replacement as well as delivering additional capacity for products capable of operating at this voltage level. Meaningful capacity and voltage was also demonstrated at 0℃ and stable performance well above 60℃ is predicted.


Figure 4 demonstrates ability of NextGens Li-CFx ASSB to support pulse currents, such as for telemetry communications, and to recover quickly from those pulses, throughout the life of the battery. Pulses of C/200, C/100, and C/75 were applied every 24 hours, with a background discharge of C/1000. Voltage drop at the highest pulse rate is relatively low at ~0.05V and continues throughout the discharge.





Mitigation of Li-CFx Swelling


Conventional CFx electrodes expand up to 100% during discharge. Manufacturers compensate by varying the cathode composition, adjusting cell design, or underfilling the cell. SEM images in Figure 5 show that NextGens SPE reduces expansion to as little as 38%. Two cell configurations were analyzed, one with solid electrolyte in the cathode plus conventional liquid electrolyte, and a second with solid electrolyte both in the cathode and as separator, i.e., ASSB, with cathode thicknesses measured before and after full discharge.


The post-discharge expansion percentages in the table below compare (1) literature data for conventional liquid electrolyte, (2) cell with NextGens SPE P1 in the cathode and liquid electrolyte in the separator, (3) cell with NextGens SPE P1 in the cathode and SPE P2 as the separator.

2. LiFePO4 Rechargeable Battery:



Figure 6 shows rate performance and cycling capacity retention for ASSB cells using LiFePO4 (LFP). Initial capacity at C/20 reached 170 mAh/g, with sustained capacity at rates as high as 1C charge/discharge. This indicates excellent rate performance for NextGens SPE in an LFP-based battery as it is challenging to achieve good rate performance with LFP, even in a liquid electrolyte system. Following the high-rate testing, cycle life testing showed excellent capacity retention with ~98% capacity projected after 500 cycles and ~96% after 1000 cycles.

3. Conclusion



NextGen optimized Li-CFx and Li-LFP all-solid-state battery (ASSB) performance with a dual-duty solid electrolyte. ASSB Li-CFx and Li-LFP cell performance is approaching that of conventional liquid-electrolyte batteries while delivering critical safety and performance advantages. These innovations position NextGen as a leader in ASSB technology with beneficial implications for a broad range of industries and for society.
